Hello everyone!

I am trying to figure out how to display particles/a particle system in a partless mod (e.g. display dust zooming by the vessel during flight or other funny things). It seems that gameObject has a particleSystem property of type ParticleSystem Ã¢â‚¬â€œ sounds good and there are Unity tutorials on how to make it work with that. However, this property is null. So AddComponent won't work because it already exists and instantiating it doesn't work because it's read-only.

Of course this might not be the best approach altogether, maybe there is a better solution to tackle this.

[KSPAddon( KSPAddon.Startup.Flight, false )]
public class CanIHazParticles : MonoBehaviour {

    // Step 1: create mod dummy
    // Step 2: ???
    // Step 3: sup3r fLy p4rt!cleZ

}

This question may come from my lack of knowledge of the Unity engine so please forgive me if the answer is rather easy. I tried to look at a few different mods to see if I can find anything, but without any luck.
Look in DeadlyReentry.cs in DRE Continued (sig). That spawns a "OW OW BURNING" particle system when parts overheat.
Thank you, I'll have a look and see how far it'll get me!

Sorry that it took me so long Ã¢â‚¬â€œ I've just been too busy at work. I finally got around to try this and with small modifications it works just fine in a partless mod. Thank you!

However, I have a follow-up question. I found this overview of available effects. However, I'd like to make a custom one Ã¢â‚¬â€œ but how? The effects seem to come from the (binary) file KSP_Data/ressources.assets, so I'm assuming this is where I'll have to actually use Unity. Before I get started with that, is it really the case that I can just create the effect in there and export a custom assets file or are there limitations with KSP?

You could just make your own particle system directly via Unity (I know it's possible since Majiir does it--check out the recently released particle mod of his). Not sure how the FX in ModuleEnginesFX work; that's like a "half custom" system. Haven't dug into it more, but I likely will soon.
